results:
Based on my search results, I found information about reviews and opinions regarding Jacek Dehnel's 2013 Polish translation of "The Great Gatsby" published by Znak. Here's what I found:

## Reception of Jacek Dehnel's Translation

The publisher Znak describes Dehnel's translation style as "captivating" and praises his "excellent translator's workshop," stating that "The Great Gatsby gains new life, becoming a disturbingly relevant and painfully close novel."

## Critical Analysis

In an interview from 2014, Dehnel himself discussed the translation, noting that "Fitzgerald used many registers, which can be heard excellently in 'The Great Gatsby.' It's not standard, transparent English - it has claws, is complex, restless. I tried to convey its peculiarities, especially since the canonical translation greatly normalized the language."(no content)The new translation was commissioned by Znak publishing house, which had been ordering new translations of classics, and took advantage of the approaching premiere of Baz Luhrmann's film adaptation.

## Reviewer Comments

One reviewer from the blog "Tramwaj nr 4" in 2017 offered detailed praise: Regarding Dehnel's new translation created for Znak's "50 na 50" series, "The translator rose to the challenge in terms of language, but deserves the greatest recognition for supplementing the book with footnotes that reveal its broader context."(no content)The reviewer notes that the afterword "briefly explains why and in which aspects the new translation is more faithful to the original than Demkowska-Bohdziewicz's 1962 work" and that Dehnel's mission was "to convey all the nuances of Fitzgerald's style and as many annotations as possible to make reading The Great Gatsby fuller."(no content)In 2013, the book was published "in a new, brilliant translation by Jacek Dehnel."

## Publication Details

The book was published as a hardcover, format 140x205, 224 pages, first edition dated May 6, 2013, ISBN: 978-83-240-2060-7, with graphic design by Kuba Sowiński.

The overall reception appears to be positive, with critics praising Dehnel's attention to maintaining Fitzgerald's stylistic complexity and his addition of helpful annotations that enhance the reading experience for Polish readers.
